revision.text:
The '''Agricultural Children Act''' was an [[Act of Parliament]] passed by the [[United Kingdom Parliament]] in 1873, which prohibited the agricultural employment of children under the age of eight<ref name=Kirkby>{{cite book|last=Kirkby|first=Peter|title=Child Labour in Britain, 1750-1870|year=2003|publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|page=60}}</ref> and also provided for the education of children involved in farm labour. As part of this, the Act stated that children could not be employed in agricultural work without parental confirmation that they had attended school a certain number of times in the preceding twelve months, specifically 250 times for children aged eight to ten and 150 times for individuals over the age of ten.<ref name=Bourdillon>{{cite book|last=Bourdillon|first=Michael F.C.|title=Rights and Wrongs of Children's Work|year=2010|publisher=Rutgers University Press|author2=Levison, Deborah|author3= Myers, William E.|author4= White, Ben|page=46}}</ref> Ultimately, the Act was ineffective,<ref name=Kirkby/><ref name=Bourdillon/> and its provisions were replaced by those of the [[Elementary Education Act 1876]] and the [[Elementary Education Act 1880]].<ref name=Horn>{{cite journal|last=Horn|first=P.L.R.|title=The Agricultural Children Act of 1873|journal=[[History of Education]]|year=1974|volume=3|issue=2|pages=27–39}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/agriculturalchil00cham|title=Agricultural Children Act, 1873|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref>
== See also == [[Agricultural Gangs Act 1867]]
==References== <references />
==External links== * [https://archive.org/details/agriculturalchil00cham A copy of the Act] at the [[Internet Archive]]
{{UK-statute-stub}}
[[Category:United Kingdom Acts of Parliament 1873]] [[Category:Agriculture legislation in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:United Kingdom Education Acts]] [[Category:Education policy in the United Kingdom]]

{{Infobox school |name = Al-Zahiriyah Library
المكتبة الظاهرية |image = Az-Zahiriyah_Library.jpg |imagesize = 200px |caption = Entrance to Al-Zahiriyah Library |motto = |established = 1277 |type = [[Public library]], [[Madrassah]] |affiliation = [[Islamic studies|Islamic]] |district = |founder = [[Sultan]] [[Baibars]] |grades = |president = |principal = |head of school = |dean = |faculty = |staff = |students = |enrollment = |athletics = |conference = |colors = |mascot = |free_label = |free_text = |free_label2 = |free_text2 = |location = {{Flagicon|Syria}} [[Damascus]], [[Syria]] |country = |coordinates = {{coord|33|30|44.5|N|36|18|18.5|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |homepage = }} The '''Az-Zahiriyah library''' ({{lang-ar|المكتبة الظاهرية}}) in [[Damascus, Syria]] dates back to 1277, taking its name from its founder [[Sultan]] [[Baibars]] (1223–1277). Building this library was his father’s idea but he died before he could achieve it. Initially Az-Zahiriah was a public school in charge of teaching [[Quranic]] sciences. The decorations, carvings, and writing on the building walls, in addition to the gate which bears geometric designs and patterns, make the library one of the most important buildings in Damascus. It is located at Bab el Barid in the [[Al-Amara]] neighborhood. The mosaics of the [[Umayyad Mosque]] gave inspiration to the decoration of the main prayer hall where a band of lavish golden floral and architectural mosaics is running around.[http://www.archnet.org/library/sites/one-site.jsp?site_id=2777 Zahiriyya Madrasa and Mausoleum of Sultan al-Zahir Baybars] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108224216/http://www.archnet.org/library/sites/one-site.jsp?site_id=2777 |date=2009-01-08 }} The manuscript department includes over 13,000 classical [[Islamic]] manuscripts, the oldest being Imam [[Ahmad ibn Hanbal]]’s ''Kitab al-zuhd'' and ''Kitab al-fada'il''. Other notable manuscripits include ''[[Ta'rikh Dimashq]]'' by [[Ibn 'Asakir]] (1105–1175), ''al-Jam bayn al-gharibayn'' by Abu `Ubaydah Ahmad ibn Muhammad Al-Harawi (d. 1010), and ''Gharib al-hadith'' by [[Ibn Qutaybah al-Dinawari]] (d. 889).Bibliography for Alternative Sources of [[Nahj al-Balagha]] The [[library]] was nationally recognized by the Syrian state in 1880. In 1919 the "[[Arab Academy of Damascus|Arab Academy]] was charged with the supervision of the al-Zahiriyya Library. … Its collection consisted at that time of the surviving manuscripts from different small libraries in Syria. … The collection grew from 2,465 manuscripts to 22,000 volumes between 1919 and 1945."{{Citation |publisher = Fitzroy Dearborn Publishers |isbn = 1579582443 |publication-place = Chicago |chapter =Middle Eastern Libraries |author=Christof Galli |url = https://openlibrary.org/books/OL3623623M/International_dictionary_of_library_histories |title = International Dictionary of Library Histories |publication-date = 2001 |id = 1579582443 }} In 1949 a legal deposit law decreed that two copies of every work published in Syria be deposited in the library. The law was not enforced until July 1983, when a presidential decree required the deposit of 5 copies of each work published by a Syrian author. In 1984 the [[Al-Assad National Library|Al-Assad Library]] became the Syrian national library, replacing al-Zahiriyah Library. Sultan Al-Zahir Baibars, also known as Rukn Uddin Baybrus (full name, al-Malik al-Zahir Rukn al-Din Baibars al-Bunduqdari) was buried in Damascus in 1277 under the dome of the Az-Zahiriyah library, established by him. As of 2011, the library's holdings included some 100,000 volumes, 13,000 manuscripts, and 50,000 periodicals.{{Citation |publisher = De Gruyter Saur |title = World Guide to Libraries |publication-date =2011 |edition =25th }} ==See also== *[[Al-Adiliyah Madrasa]] *[[Nur al-Din Madrasa]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Madrasas in Syria}} {{Damascus}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zahiriyah, Madrasa Az}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1277]] [[Category:Libraries in Syria]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Damascus]] [[Category:Mamluk architecture in Syria]] [[Category:Mausoleums in Syria]] [[Category:Buildings and structures inside the walled city of Damascus]] [[Category:Madrasas in Damascus]] [[Category:National libraries|Syria]] [[Category:Education in Damascus]] [[Category:13th-century establishments in the Mamluk Sultanate (Cairo)]]

{{Infobox television | show_name = Amish Grace | image = Amish_Grace_Poster.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Promotional poster | genre = | creator = | based_on = [[West Nickel Mines School shooting]] | writer = Sylvie White and Teena Booth | screenplay = | story = | director = Dylan Scharping | starring = [[Kimberly Williams-Paisley]]
[[Tammy Blanchard]]
[[Matt Letscher]] | narrated = | theme_music_composer = Joseph Conlan | country = United States | language = English | num_episodes = | producer = [[Larry A. Thompson]] | editor = Anita Brandt-Burgoyne | cinematography = | runtime = 88 minutes | company = | distributor = | budget = | network = [[Lifetime Movie Network]] | first_aired = {{Start date|2010|3|28}} | last_aired = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Amish Grace''''' is a television film that premiered on the [[Lifetime Movie Network]] on [[Palm Sunday]], March 28, 2010. The movie is based on the 2006 [[West Nickel Mines School shooting]] at [[Nickel Mines, Pennsylvania]], and the spirit of forgiveness the [[Amish]] community demonstrated in its aftermath.{{cite news |title=Amish Grace |work=myLifetime |date=2010-04-09 |url=http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/amish-grace |accessdate=2010-04-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100330142755/http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/amish-grace |archivedate=2010-03-30 }} The movie stars [[Kimberly Williams-Paisley]], [[Tammy Blanchard]], and [[Matt Letscher]]{{cite news | title= Amish Grace | work= [[IMDb]] | date=2010-04-09 |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1559025/ | accessdate=2010-04-09}} and is based on the book ''Amish Grace: How Forgiveness Transcended Tragedy'', Jossey-Bass, 2007, {{ISBN|0-7879-9761-7}}, by [[Donald Kraybill]], [[Steven Nolt]], and David L. Weaver-Zercher.{{cite news | title= Amish Grace: How Forgiveness Transcended Tragedy (Hardcover) | work=Amazon | date=2010-04-09 | url = https://www.amazon.com/Amish-Grace-Forgiveness-Transcended-Tragedy/dp/0787997617 | accessdate=2010-04-09}}{{cite news | title= Amish Grace: How Forgiveness Transcended Tragedy | work=Amish Grace | date=2010-04-09 | url = http://www.amishgrace.com/ | accessdate=2010-04-09}} ''Amish Grace'' was executive-produced by [[Larry A. Thompson]], written by Sylvie White and Teena Booth, and directed by Gregg Champion. ==Plot== When a group of Amish schoolgirls are taken hostage and killed in their classroom, their parents and the Amish community of [[Nickel Mines, Pennsylvania]], stun the outside world by immediately forgiving the killer. Ida Graber ([[Kimberly Williams-Paisley]]), mother of one of the murdered children, has a tougher time than the others accepting the tragedy, but in her anguish and pain, she begins a personal journey of renewed faith, ultimately accepting the heart-wrenching tragedy of losing a child after learning that her murdered daughter, Mary Beth Graber, had promised to pray for the perpetrator before her death; reconnecting with her husband ([[Matt Letscher]]), family, and community; offering forgiveness to the killer; and even showing kindness and compassion to the killer's widow ([[Tammy Blanchard]]) and children — all in the form of Amish grace. The film implies that Charles Roberts' motive was that when his daughter died the day she was born, he decided to "get revenge on God" by taking ''his'' girls on account of how devout the Amish are. The film was dedicated in memory of the victims of the West Nickel Mines School shooting. ==Cast== * [[Kimberly Williams-Paisley]] as Ida Graber, an Amish mother who loses her elder child in the shooting and learns forgiveness from the tragedy. * [[Tammy Blanchard]] as Amy Roberts, the widow of Charlie Roberts whom Ida refuses to accept. * [[Matt Letscher]] as Gideon Graber, the husband of Ida Graber and father of Mary Beth and Katie Graber. * [[Fay Masterson]] as Jill Green, a television reporter whom Ida befriends. * [[Karley Scott Collins]] as Katie Graber, the younger daughter of Ida and Gideon who escapes before the shooting. * John Churchill as Charlie Roberts, the perpetrator of the school shooting who commits suicide after firing at the victims. * [[Gary Graham]] as Henry Taskey. * [[Darcy Rose Byrnes]] as Rebecca Knepp, a survived victim whom at the end reveals that Mary Beth Graber has forgiven Charlie Roberts. * [[Eugene Byrd]] as Danny, a camera man who works with Jill Green * [[Amy Sloan]] as Rachel Knepp, a survived victim and sister of Rebecca Knepp. * [[Madison Davenport]] as Mary Beth Graber, the elder daughter of Ida and Gideon who promises to pray for the perpetrator before she is killed. * [[Willow Geer]] as Judith. * [[Jim Metzler]] as County Sheriff. * [[David Mazouz]] as Andy Roberts, a son of Charlie Roberts. ==Ratings== ''Amish Grace'' broke network records in multiple [[demographics]], with more than 4 million viewers, becoming the highest-rated and most-watched original movie in Lifetime Movie Network’s history in Households (3.8/2,916,449 viewers), Total Viewers (2.0/4,020,496), Women 18+ (3.5/2,729,834), Women 25-54 (2.7/1,156,363), Adults 18+ (2.4/3,649,266) and Adults 25-54 (1.9/1,585,667).{{cite news | last = Reynolds | first = Mike | title= 'Amish Grace' Delivers As Highest-Rated Original Telepic In Lifetime Movie Network History | work=Multichannel News | date=2010-03-29 | url = http://www.multichannel.com/article/450814-_Amish_Grace_Delivers_As_Highest_Rated_Original_Telepic_In_Lifetime_Movie_Network_History.php | accessdate=2010-04-09}}{{cite news | last = Seidman | first = Robert | title= Lifetime Movie Network’s ''Amish Grace'' Breaks Records With 4.02 Million Viewers | work= TV by the Numbers | date=2010-03-29 | url = http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/03/29/lifetime-movie-networks-amish-grace-breaks-records-with-4-02-million-viewers/46478 | accessdate=2010-04-09}}{{cite news | last = Kissell | first = Rick | title= 7.6 million watch ''Kids’ Choice Awards'' | work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=2010-03-29 |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118017057.html?categoryid=1275&cs=1&query=Amish+Grace+-+Ratings | accessdate=2010-04-09}}{{cite news | title= ''Amish Grace'' breaks Lifetime Movie Net records | work= The Hollywood Reporter | date=2010-03-29 |url=http://www.thrfeed.com/2010/03/amish-grace-breaks-lifetime-movie-net-records.html | accessdate=2010-04-09}} ==Reception== The movie mostly received positive reviews;{{cite news | last = Lowry | first = Brian | title= Amish Grace | work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=2010-03-25 |url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117942472.html?categoryid=32&cs=1 | accessdate=2010-04-09}}{{cite news | title= Six Picks: Recommendations from the Monitor staff | work= The Christian Science Monitor | date=2010-03-22 |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/The-Culture/Arts/2010/0322/Six-Picks-Recommendations-from-the-Monitor-staff | accessdate=2010-04-09}}{{cite news | last = Boatwright | first = Phil | title= And on TV…Amish Grace | work= Preview Online | date=2010-04-05 |url=http://www.previewonline.org/holyholly/amishgrace.html | accessdate=2010-04-09}}{{cite news | last = Cooper | first = Jackie K. | title= ''Amish Grace'' Is A Story Of Grace Under Fire | work= The Huffington Post | date=2010-03-23 |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jackie-k-cooper/emamish-graceem-is-a-stor_b_507564.html?view=print | accessdate=2010-04-09}}{{cite news |last=Baehr |first=Dr. Ted |last2=Holder |first2=Jeff |title=AMISH GRACE – Coming to a Greater Understanding of God’s Grace |work=Movie Guide |date=2010-03-22 |url=http://www.movieguide.org/articles/1/714/amish-grace-coming-to-a-greater-understanding-of-gods-grace |accessdate=2010-04-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100324213402/http://www.movieguide.org/articles/1/714/amish-grace-coming-to-a-greater-understanding-of-gods-grace |archivedate=2010-03-24 }}{{cite news | last = Walker | first = Angela | title= Amish Grace Is Amazing | work= Christian Cinema | date=2010-04-09 |url=http://www.christiancinema.com/catalog/article_info.php?articles_id=7250&src=rss | accessdate=2010-04-09}} however, it received criticism because the authors of ''Amish Grace: How Forgiveness Transcended Tragedy'', Jossey-Bass, 2007, {{ISBN|0-7879-9761-7}}, distanced themselves from the production out of respect to the Amish community.{{cite news | title= Movie on West Nickel Mines School shooting draws criticism | work= Associated Press | publisher= USA Today | date=2010-03-24 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2010-03-24-amish-shooting_N.htm | accessdate=2010-04-09}} Others criticized the movie for blending facts with fiction.{{cite news |last = DeJesus |first = Ivey |title = ''Amish Grace'' movie fictionalizes Nickel Mines tragedy, generates debate |work = PennLive.com |publisher = The Patriot-News |date = 2010-03-07 |url = http://blog.pennlive.com/midstate_impact/print.html?entry=/2010/03/controversial_amish_grace_movi.html |accessdate = 2010-04-09 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20100324161134/http://blog.pennlive.com/midstate_impact/print.html?entry=%2F2010%2F03%2Fcontroversial_amish_grace_movi.html |archive-date = 2010-03-24 |dead-url = yes |df = }} ==Awards== * Nominated for the [[Humanitas Prize]]{{cite news | title= Finalists Announced for 36th Annual HUMANITAS Prize Honoring Great Television and Film Writing | work= PR Newswire | date=2010-07-14 |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/finalists-announced-for-36th-annual-humanitas-prize-honoring-great-television-and-film-writing-98438949.html | accessdate=2011-03-22}} * Winner of the [[MOVIEGUIDE]] [https://movieguideawards.com/2011-movieguide-awards-winners/ Epiphany Prize for Most Inspiring TV Program] of 2010{{cite news | title= 19th Annual MOVIEGUIDE® Faith & Values Awards Gala and Report to the Entertainment Industry | work= MOVIEGUIDE | date=2011-02-18 |url=http://www.movieguide.org/articles/main/19th-annual-movieguider-faith-a-values-awards-gala-and-report-to-the-entertainment-industry.html | accessdate=2011-03-22}} * Madison Mason won the [https://movieguideawards.com/2011-movieguide-awards-winners/ Grace Award for Television] at the [https://movieguideawards.com/ 2011 Movieguide Awards] for Amish Grace. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1559025}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Amish Grace}} [[Category:2010 television films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Amish in films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films set in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Lifetime (TV network) films]] [[Category:Films about school violence]] revision.comment: /* Additional information */ Added the Jim Rose Report, with a link.
revision.text:
{{For|understanding the method used to teach students how to read through analytical approaches|Synthetic phonics|Phonetics}} {{Reading}} {{IPA notice}}
'''Analytical phonics''' refers to an approach to the teaching of reading in which the [[phonemes]] associated with particular [[graphemes]] are not pronounced in isolation. Children identify (analyze) the common [[phoneme]] in a set of words in which each word contains the phoneme under study. For example, teacher and pupils discuss how the following words are alike: pat, park, push and pen. Analytic phonics for writing similarly relies on inferential learning: realising that the initial phoneme in /p i g/ is the same as that in /p æ t, p a: k, p u ƒ/ and /p e n/, children deduce that they must write that phoneme with grapheme.<ref>[http://www.literacytrust.org.uk/Database/Primary/phonicsdef.html National Literacy Trust]</ref> Today, Analytical phonics is referred to as '''Implicit phonics.''' This is because it signifies the analysis (breaking down) of the whole word to its parts (an analysis only necessary when a child cannot read it as a whole word).<ref>[http://www.ednews.org/articles/528/1/Some-issues-in-phonics-instruction-Implicit-and-explicit-phonics-instruction/Page1.html Education News]</ref>
==Practice and approach== Implicit phonics is moving from the whole to the smallest parts; "blending-and-building" is not usually taught. A student will identify new words by its shape, beginning and ending letters, any context clues from the rest of the sentence or any accompanying pictures.<ref>[http://www.nrrf.org/essay_Explicit_or_Implicit_Phonics.html The National Right to Read Foundation]</ref>
==Shortcomings of this approach== A major problem with analytical phonic methods is the erroneous assumption that all students will already have the fairly sophisticated phonemic awareness skills needed to enable the comparison of sounds within the various words. Implicit instruction relies on readers "discovering" clues about sound-spelling relationships; good readers can do this, but poor readers are not likely to do so.<ref>[http://content.scholastic.com/browse/article.jsp?id=4500 Scholastic] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070809223022/http://content.scholastic.com/browse/article.jsp?id=4500 |date=August 9, 2007 }}</ref>
==Controversy: analytical vs. synthetic approaches== [[Phonics]] has become an acceptable practice and approach to teaching children to read. However, there are different methods in which it is used, and disagreement over which approach is best.
There are two primary approaches to teaching phonics: analytical phonics and [[synthetic phonics]]. Both approaches require the learner to have some phonological awareness (the ability to hear and discriminate sounds in spoken words). Both approaches can also contribute to furthering children's phonological development. Phonological awareness is an essential skill for reading, writing, listening and talking.
Synthetic phonics involves the development of phonemic awareness from the outset. As part of the decoding process, the reader learns up to 44 phonemes (the smallest units of sound) and their related graphemes (the written symbols for the phoneme).
In contrast, analytical phonics, also known as the "whole word" approach, involves analysis of whole words to detect phonetic or orthographic (spelling) patterns, then splitting them into smaller parts to help with decoding.<ref>[http://www.ltscotland.org.uk/5to14/specialfocus/earlyintervention/issues/phonics.asp Learning and Teaching Scotland] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511194552/http://www.ltscotland.org.uk/5to14/specialfocus/earlyintervention/issues/phonics.asp |date=May 11, 2008 }}</ref>
Supporters of [[Synthetic phonics]] argue that if the systematic teaching of phonics doesn't take place, analytic learners can fall behind and fail to develop the tools they need for decoding words.<ref>[http://www.education-world.com/a_curr/curr029.shtml Education World]</ref>
==See also== *[[Reading (process)|Reading]] *[[Phonemic awareness]] *[[Phonetics]] *[[Phonics]] *[[Synthetic phonics]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Additional information== *[http://www.synthetic-phonics.com/whole_word.html Synthetic Phonics - Whole Word] *[http://www.readingrockets.org/article/254 Reading Rockets] *[http://faculty.salisbury.edu/~wdhammond/A%20Short%20Course%20On%20Phonics.doc A Short Course on Phonics] *[http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20130321055757/https://www.education.gov.uk/publications/eOrderingDownload/0201-2006PDF-EN-01.pdf Independent review of the teaching of early reading: Final Report Jim Rose 2006]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Analytical phonics}} [[Category:Phonics]] [[Category:Phonetics]] [[Category:Reading (process)]]

{{Use British English|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox website |name = |logo = [[File:BBC domesday reloaded.png|255px|BBC Domesday Reloaded logo]] |logocaption =   <!-- White space to separate from screenshot below: no need to title it "Logo" or similar --> |screenshot = [[File:BBC domesday reloaded screenshot.png|255px|BBC Domesday Reloaded screenshot]] |collapsible = |collapsetext = |caption = Screenshot showing a written account from {{nowrap|D-block GB-540000-252000}} |url = {{url|http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20110911075344/http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/domesday}} |slogan = |commercial = Yes |type = |registration = None |language = English |content license = |owner = [[BBC]] |author = |launch date = {{Start date and age|df=yes|2011|05|12}}<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2011/05_may/12/domesday.shtml | title = BBC Domesday Reloaded unveils rarely-seen local material from 1986 | accessdate = 2011-05-13 | publisher = [[BBC]] | date = 2011-05-12 | quote = [...] has been unearthed through BBC Domesday Reloaded [...] }} </ref> |alexa = |revenue = |current status = Archived, non-functioning (July 2018) }} '''BBC Domesday Reloaded''' was a [[local history]] [[web site]] for the digitised content of the [[BBC]]'s 1986 [[BBC Domesday Project|Domesday Project]]. It was launched in May 2011<ref>[http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/news/573.htm The National Archives - the UK government's official archive]</ref><ref name="wired behind">{{cite news | url=https://www.wired.co.uk/podcast/episode-24 | title=Behind the BBC's Domesday Reloaded | work=[[Wired UK]] | date=6 May 2011 | accessdate=7 November 2011 | author=Lanxon, Nate}}</ref><ref name="historyextra domesday reloaded">{{cite news | url=http://www.historyextra.com/blog/domesday-reloaded | title=Domesday Reloaded | work=[[BBC History]] | date=12 May 2011 | accessdate=7 November 2011 | author=Musgrove, Dave | quote=Domesday Reloaded reopens to the public the material that was gathered 25 years ago for the BBC Domesday project.}}</ref><ref name="pocket-lint reloaded for the internet age">{{cite web | url=http://www.pocket-lint.com/news/39906/domesday-reloaded-bbc-project-1986 | title=BBC Domesday Project Reloaded for the Internet age | publisher=Pocket-lint | date=6 May 2011 | accessdate=7 November 2011 | author=Sung, Dan | quote=In a matter of days, all of that information will finally be available to see online as Domesday Reloaded.}}</ref><ref name="e2bn.org domesday reloaded">{{cite web|url=http://www.e2bn.org/news/307/domesday-reloaded.html |title=Domesday Reloaded |publisher=[[East of England Broadband Network]] |accessdate=7 November 2011 |quote=Today, the BBC launched the Domesday Reloaded website. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111017115624/http://www.e2bn.org/news/307/domesday-reloaded.html |archivedate=17 October 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> and included some updates contributed by users during 2011. During the site's first day of public operation, over two million pages were viewed.<ref name="bbc bletchley park">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-16053184 | title=Domesday Reloaded Project opens at Bletchley Park | work=[[BBC News]] | date=7 December 2011 | accessdate=8 December 2011 | author=Lee, Dave | quote=The BBC's Domesday Project has been made into an interactive 'touchtable' now on display at The National Museum of Computing at Bletchley Park. [...] Over two million pages were viewed on the website's first day open to the public.}}</ref>
==History==
The BBC said that it worked with [[The National Archives (UK)|The National Archives]] to transfer the material.<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2011/05_may/06/domesday.shtml | title = BBC Learning takes you back to Eighties with Domesday Reloaded | accessdate = 2011-05-13 | date = 2011-05-06 | publisher = [[BBC]] | quote = BBC Learning has been working very closely with The National Archives and with their help and expertise in web archiving and digital preservation, this valuable resource will be available to the public for generations to come. | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110513004709/http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2011/05_may/06/domesday.shtml| archivedate= 13 May 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}} </ref> The data was extracted to a [[PC compatible]] computer by communication{{How|date=July 2018}} with a [[BBC Master]] computer which could read the disks from the original system. The transfer was facilitated by Simon Guerrero and Andy Finney, who were involved in the original project (Andy as an engineer and Simon as a teenage contributor).{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}}
In December 2011, the BBC announced installations of large horizontally installed (table-style) [[touchscreen]] interfaces to the data, known as "TouchTable". They are housed at its [[MediaCityUK]] site in [[City of Salford|Salford]] and [[The National Museum of Computing]] in [[Bletchley]].<ref name="bbc bletchley park" /><ref name="how-do mediacity">{{cite web|url=http://www.how-do.co.uk/north-west-media-news/other-media/mediacity-to-house-domesday-data-20111202100956063 |title=MediaCity to house Domesday data |publisher=How-Do |date=2 December 2011 |accessdate=8 December 2011 |quote=[...] housed in what the BBC describes as a "touchable" – a computer that allows up to four people at once to search maps, photos and articles of the UK in 1986 and 2011. [...] Another "touchable" will be housed at the National Museum of Computing at Bletchley Park. Saul Nassé, Controller of BBC Learning, said: "[...] with the touchable [...]" |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120108011525/http://www.how-do.co.uk/north-west-media-news/other-media/mediacity-to-house-domesday-data-20111202100956063 |archivedate=8 January 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="theregister put on touchscreen">{{cite web | url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2011/12/08/bbc_domesday_touchtable_bletchley_park/ | title=Domesday Book put on touchscreen at Bletchley Park | work=[[The Register]] | date=8 December 2011 | accessdate=8 December 2011 | author=Leach, Anna | quote=Unveiled today, the Domesday Touchtable will let four users at a time browse through the 50GB of info including 25,000 photographs. There are two Domesday Touchtables in the country - the second is in the BBC's Manchester MediaCity campus.}}</ref> The TouchTables used have a diagonal [[display size]] of 52 inches, which exceeded the largest LCD-based {{nowrap|[[Microsoft PixelSense|Surface 2.0]]}} screen available at the time.<ref name="techcrunch archives on touchtable">{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/12/07/uks-domesday-reloaded-archives-on-touch-table-at-bletchley-park/ | title=UK's "Domesday Reloaded" Archives On Touch-Table At Bletchley Park | work=[[TechCrunch]] | date=7 December 2011 | accessdate=8 December 2011 | author=Coldewey, Devin | quote=[...] also put together a touch-enabled version for a Surface-like touchscreen table. It’s not actually a Surface; the 52-inch screen is larger than the latest Samsung-based Surface 2.0 [...]}}</ref> The TouchTables were reported to have been developed by eMoot<ref name="zdnet table developed">{{cite news|url=http://www.zdnet.co.uk/blogs/jacks-blog-10017212/bbcs-multitouch-domesday-table-developed-by-emoot-10024978/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130505103214/http://www.zdnet.co.uk/blogs/jacks-blog-10017212/bbcs-multitouch-domesday-table-developed-by-emoot-10024978/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 May 2013 |title=BBC's multitouch Domesday table developed by eMoot |work=[[ZDNet]] |date=8 December 2011 |accessdate=15 December 2011 |author=Schofield, Jack |quote=[...] it appears that the Domesday Touchtable was developed by London-based eMoot Limited. |authorlink=Jack Schofield (journalist) }}</ref> and allow up to four users to browse through the information at the same time,<ref name="theregister put on touchscreen" /> using 12 touch points simultaneously.<ref name="miltonkeynes.co.uk domesday comes">{{cite news | url=http://www.miltonkeynes.co.uk/news/local/domesday_comes_to_national_museum_of_computing_1_3333398 | title=Domesday comes to National Museum of Computing | work=[[Milton Keynes Citizen]] | date=16 December 2011 | accessdate=16 December 2011 | location=Milton Keynes | quote=The interface has 12 simultaneous touch-points [...]}}</ref>
The website was transferred to The National Archives in June 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/domesday|title=The Last Post|last=Mansfield|first=Alex|date=|website=BBC Domesday Reloaded|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=9 July 2018}}</ref>
==Main features==
The website provided online access to images and articles from the original Domesday Project. Visitors were able to update information from their local area<ref>[http://www.whodoyouthinkyouaremagazine.com/news/1980s-domesday-reloaded-data-goes-online 1980s Domesday Reloaded data goes online]</ref> until the end of October 2011.<ref name="domesday1986 submissions end today">{{cite web|url=http://domesday1986.com/node/53 |title=Domesday Reloaded Submissions end Today |publisher=Domesday Special Interest Group |date=31 October 2011 |accessdate=7 November 2011 |author=Grant, Darren |quote=[...] October the 31st is the last day for submissions. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207112553/http://www.domesday1986.com/node/53 |archivedate=7 February 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref><ref name="bbc blogs last chance">{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/domesday/ | title=Last chance to update Domesday Reloaded: Make your mark on history | publisher=[[BBC]] | date=14 October 2011 | accessdate=7 November 2011 | author=Copeman, Neil | quote=On the 31st October it's time for us to close Domesday Reloaded to updates and new submissions. [...] We're doing this to mark the end of the 2011 project and to enable The National Archives to capture the site and preserve the data [...]}}</ref> Some local libraries hosted events for residents to contribute updates to the site.<ref name="derbyshiretimes listings guide">{{cite news | url=http://www.derbyshiretimes.co.uk/lifestyle/what-s-on/listings_guide_1_3897753 | title=Listings guide | work=[[Derbyshire Times]] | date=21 October 2011 | accessdate=7 November 2011 | quote=Local Studies Day, Bring your 1980s memorabilia: toys, games, fashion, stories and memories. The aim is to update the 1986 BBC Domesday information for Whitwell on the Domesday Reloaded site at Whitwell Library, See www.bbc.co.uk/history/domesday 2pm till 5pm.}}</ref><ref name="bradleystokejournal event">{{cite web | url=http://www.bradleystokejournal.co.uk/2011/05/17/library-stage-bbc-domesday-reloaded-event/ | title=Library to stage BBC Domesday Reloaded event | publisher=Bradley Stoke Journal | date=17 May 2011 | accessdate=7 November 2011 | quote=Bradley Stoke Library is staging a “Back to the ’80s” event on Saturday (21st May) to mark the 25th anniversary of the BBC’s Domesday Project.}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{Official}} Archived, non-functioning (July 2018) * [http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/catalogue/displaycataloguedetails.asp?CATLN=3&CATID=61940&j=1 The National Archives Series reference PRO 30/100: Data from BBC Domesday Project]
