{{Infobox legislation |short_title = Bantu Education Act, 1953 |legislature = |image = Coat of Arms of South Africa (1932-2000).svg |imagesize = |imagealt = |caption = |long_title = Act to provide for the transfer of the administration and control of native education from the several provincial administrations to the Government of the Union, and for matters incidental thereto. |citation = Act No. 47 of 1953 |territorial_extent = |enacted_by = [[Parliament of South Africa]] |date_enacted = |date_passed = |enacted_by2 = |date_enacted2 = |date_passed2 = |date_assented = |royal_assent = 5 October 1986 |date_signed = |date_commenced = 1 January 1954 |date_of_expiry = |date_repealed = 1 January 1980 |administered_by = [[Minister of Bantu Administration and Development, and Bantu Education|Minister of Native Affairs]] |bill = |bill_citation = |bill_date = |introduced_by = |1st_reading = |2nd_reading = |3rd_reading = |conf_committee_passed = |bill2 = |bill_citation2 = |bill_date2 = |introduced_by2 = |1st_reading2 = |2nd_reading2 = |3rd_reading2 = |conf_committee_passed2 = |date_conf_committee = |white_paper = |committee_report = |amendments = |repeals = [[Education and Training Act, 1979]] |related_legislation = |summary = |keywords = |status = repealed }} The '''Bantu Education Act, 1953''' (Act No. 47 of 1953; later renamed the '''Black Education Act, 1953''') was a [[South Africa]]n segregation law which legalised several aspects of the [[apartheid]] system passed by the Apartheid regime which was really not on the side of the black community. Its major provision was enforcing racially separated educational facilities.{{Cite web|url=http://repository.up.ac.za/bitstream/handle/2263/53445/Moore_Class_2016.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y|title=IN CLASS OF THEIR OWN: THE BANTU EDUCATION ACT (1953) REVISITED|last=Nadine L. Moore|first=Faculty of Humanities University of Pretoria|date=2015|website=|access-date=}} Even [[University|universities]] were made "tribal", and all but three missionary schools chose to close down when the government no longer would help support their schools. Very few authorities continued using their own finances to support education for native Africans.{{Cite book| last = Clark | first = Nancy L. | authorlink = |author2=Worger, William H. | title = South Africa - The Rise and Fall of Apartheid |series = Seminar Studies in History| publisher = Pearson Education Limited | year = 2004 | location = | pages = 48–52 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6JTRPzhoH4cC&printsec=frontcover&dq=isbn=0582414377#PPP1,M1| doi = | id = | isbn = 0-582-41437-7 }} In 1959, this type of education was extended to "non white" universities and colleges with the [[Extension of University Education Act]], and the internationally prestigious [[Fort Hare University|University College of Fort Hare]] was taken over by the government and degraded to being part of the Bantu education system.[http://www.ufh.ac.za/timeline.html# Timeline of the University: 1959] n{{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071230083858/http://www.ufh.ac.za/timeline.html%23 |date=December 30, 2007 }}. Official website of University of Fort Hare. Accessed 2007-12-03. It is often argued that the policy of Bantu (African) education was aimed to direct black or non-white youth to the unskilled labour market, although Kiyaam Govind, at the time Minister of Native Affairs, claimed that the aim was to solve South Africa's "ethnic problems" by creating complementary economic and political units for different ethnic group. The [[National Party (South Africa)|national authorities of the time]] is often said to have viewed education as having a rather pivotal position in their goal of eventually separating South Africa from the Bantustans entirely. The Minister of Native Affairs at the time, the "Architect of Apartheid" [[Hendrik Verwoerd]], stated that:
"There is no place for [the Bantu] in the European community above the level of certain forms of labour ... What is the use of teaching the Bantu child mathematics when it cannot use it in practice?"
The introduction of Bantu Education led to a substantial increase of government funding to the learning institutions of black Africans, but it did not keep up with population increase.Giliomee H, 2009. ''A Note on Bantu Education 1953-1970'' South African Journal of Economics, March 2009. The law forced institutions under the direct control of the state and solve white man problems. The National Party now had the power to employ and train teachers as they saw fit. Black teachers' salaries in 1953 were extremely low and resulted in a dramatic drop of trainee teachers. Only one third of the black teachers were qualified. The schools reserved for the country's white children were of Western standards. 30% of the black schools did not have electricity, 25% no running water and less than half had plumbing. The education for Blacks, Indians and Coloureds was substantially cheaper but not free. In the 70s, the per capita governmental spending on black education was one-tenth of the spending on white.{{Cite book| last = Byrnes | first = Rita M. | authorlink = | title = South Africa: A Country Study | publisher = GPO for the Library of Congress | year = 1996 | location = Washington | pages = | url = http://countrystudies.us/south-africa/ | doi = | id = | isbn = }} In 1976, the ''Afrikaans Medium Decree'' of 1974, which forced all black schools to use both [[Afrikaans]] and English as languages of instruction beginning with the last year of primary school, led to the [[Soweto Uprising]] in which more than 575 people died, at least 134 of them under the age of eighteen.{{cite web|url=http://africanhistory.about.com/library/bl/blsaJune16decree.htm|title=The Afrikaans Medium Decree that Led to the Soweto Uprising|website=about.com|accessdate=15 September 2017}} The act was repealed in 1979 by the [[Education and Training Act, 1979]], which continued the system of racially segregated education, while also eliminating both discrimination in tuition fees and the segregated Department of Bantu Education and allowing the both use of native tongue education up to the fourth grade and limited attendance at private schools as well.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sq43lnbklEUC&pg=PA119&lpg=PA119&dq=1979+south+african+education+and+training+act&source=bl&ots=arS1e7r4pN&sig=QaEHHY_aOnRgIh7PgdlxkENlhGQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj-_bfyqc_UAhVL54MKHT8KAmUQ6AEIRzAF#v=onepage&q=1979+south+african+education+and+training+act&f=false|title=South Africa: Time Running Out : the Report of the Study Commission on U.S. Policy Toward Southern Africa|first=Study Commission on U. S. Policy toward Southern Africa|last=(U.S.)|date=15 September 1981|publisher=University of California Press|accessdate=15 September 2017|via=Google Books}} Segregation became unconstitutional after the introduction of the [[Interim Constitution of South Africa|Interim Constitution]] in 1994, and most sections of the Education and Training Act were repealed by the [[South African Schools Act, 1996]]. == References == {{Reflist}} http://nmmu.ac.za/documents/mward/Bantu%20Education%20Act%201953.pdf{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051201041632/http://www.socsci.kun.nl/ped/whp/histeduc/apartheid.html Article on apartheid and education that mentions the Bantu Act] (in Dutch) * https://www.sahistory.org.za/archive/bantu-education-act%2C-act-no-47-of-1953 {{Apartheid legislation navbox}} [[Category:1953 in South African law]] [[Category:Apartheid laws in South Africa]] [[Category:1953 in international relations]] [[Category:Education law]]

revision.comment: clean up;fix depreciated parameters for infobox school using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
Updated to include Catholic Earthcare's staff changes and new position within Caritas Australia
revision.text:
'''Catholic Earthcare Australia''' is an agency of the Australian [[Catholic]] [[Bishop]]s Conference and is the environmental arm of the [[Catholic Church in Australia|Catholic Church]] in [[Australia]]. This executive agency of the Bishops' Commission for Justice and Development (BCJD) is mandated with the mission of advising, supporting and assisting the BCJD in responding to [[Pope John Paul II]]'s call to "stimulate and sustain the ecological conversion" throughout the Catholic church in Australia and beyond.<ref>Vision of Catholic Earthcare {{cite web |url=http://www.catholicearthcare.org.au/mandate.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120803220513/http://www.catholicearthcare.org.au/mandate.html |archivedate=2012-08-03 |df= }}. accessed 18 May 2010</ref>
In May 2017, the Australian Catholic Bishops Conference decided to incorporate Catholic Earthcare Australia into its sister agency, Caritas Australia. This change was made to strengthen the capacity of Catholic Earthcare Australia, particularly in advocating and educating about the principles of Holy Father’s 2015 encyclical, Laudato Si, and to achieve synergies with Caritas Australia’s extensive education and advocacy work around Australia, including parishes, schools and the wider Catholic community on environmental issues such as climate change.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://catholicearthcare.org.au/|title=Catholic Earthcare Australia - Caring for Creation|website=Catholic Earthcare Australia|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref>
==Mandate from the Australian Bishops== ;Tasks and Responsibilities<ref>Mandate from the Australian Bishops [http://catholicearthcare.org.au/about/]. accessed 25 August 2015</ref> Catholic Earthcare Australia will act as an advisory agency to the BCJD on ecological matters, including the safeguarding of the integrity of creation, environmental justice and ecological [[sustainability]].
;Its tasks will include: * carrying out research, from the perspective of scripture and the Church's environmental and social justice teachings; * developing national networks, with a view to initiating, linking, resourcing and supporting ecological endeavours within the Church, and extending the hand of friendship and cooperation to other like-minded groups working in the broader community; * undertaking initiatives by encouraging a reverence for creation, a responsible stewardship of Earth's natural resources and ecosystems, and providing a voice for the victims of pollution, environmental degradation and injustice; * providing educational materials and services to Catholic schools, organisations, congregations and parishes - particularly information to assist in the carrying out of environmental audits and the implementation of more ecologically and ethically sustainable practices.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.catholicearthcare.org.au Catholic Earthcare]
[[Category:Christianity and environmentalism]] [[Category:Environment and religion]] [[Category:Environmental education by region]] [[Category:Catholic Church in Australia]]
{{Australia-org-stub}}

'''Certified Penetration Testing Engineer (C)PTE)''' is an internationally recognized [[computer security|cyber security]] certification administered by the [[United States]]-based [[information security]] company [[Mile2]]. The accreditation maps to the [[Committee on National Security Systems]]' [[CNSSI-4013|4013 education certification]].<ref>[https://mile2.com/information-systems-security-infosec-professionals "National Security Agency (NSA) and the Committee on National Security Systems (CNSS) recognizes Mile2’s certification course ware," Mile2], retrieved January 9, 2014.</ref> The C)PTE certification is considered one of five core cyber security certifications.<ref>[http://www.monster.com/technology/a/Getting-a-Job-in-IT-Security "What you need to know about getting a job in IT security," by Kelly O'Hara, Monster, November 21, 2014], retrieved January 17, 2014.</ref>
==Accreditations==
Obtaining the C)PTE certification requires proven proficiency and knowledge of five key [[information security]] elements, [[penetration test]]ing, [[data collection]], scanning, [[enumeration]], exploitation and reporting.<ref>[http://www.mile2.com/penetration%20testing%20ethical%20hacking/cpte.html "Internationally Recognized Cyber Security Studies", Mile2], retrieved January 9, 2014.</ref>
The C)PTE certification is one of several information assurance accreditations recognized by the U.S. [[National Security Agency]].<ref>[https://www.nsa.gov/ia/academic_outreach/iace_program/iace_certified_institutions.shtml#fl "IA Courseware Institutions," U.S. National Security Agency website], retrieved January 10, 2014.</ref> The certification has also been approved by the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|U.S. Department of Homeland Security]]'s National Initiative for Cyber Security Studies and Careers (NICSS) and the U.S.-based National Security Systems Committee.<ref>[http://niccs.us-cert.gov/training/tc/search/detail/1316 "Mile2 Certified Penetration Testing Engineer (C)PTE)," U.S. National Security Agency National Initiative for Cyber Security], retrieved January 9, 2014.</ref>
==Examination==
The online exam for C)PTE accreditation lasts two hours and consists of 100 multiple choice questions.<ref>[http://www.mile2.com/penetration-testing-ethical-hacking/cpte.html "Mile2 is NSA/CNSS Accredited," Mile 2], retrieved January 9, 2014.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.mile2.com/penetration-testing-ethical-hacking/cpte.html Mile2 C)PTE website page]
{{Computer Security Certifications}} [[Category:Computer security qualifications]] [[Category:Data security]] [[Category:Information technology qualifications]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
[[Charter schools]] in [[New Zealand]], labelled as '''Partnership Schools''' or '''''Kura Hourua''''', receive government funding similar to state schools but are subject to fewer rules and regulations from the Ministry of Education.<ref name=nh-2011/> They are free and open for any students to attend. Charter schools have the autonomy to set their own curriculum, qualifications, pay rates for teachers, school-hours and school terms. The schools may be operated by sponsors such as Māori [[Iwi]], not-for-profit organisations, businesses or existing education providers.<ref name=nh-2011/>
Charter schools were legalized after an agreement between the [[New Zealand National Party|National Party]] and the [[ACT Party]] following the [[New Zealand general election, 2011|2011 general election]]. In October 2012, the controversial Education Amendment Bill creating charter schools passed with a five-vote majority.<ref name="Education Amendment Bill">{{cite web |url= http://www.parliament.nz/NR/rdonlyres/5D239E36-32A4-4887-A674-A959B42197D3/269654/DBSCH_SCR_5823_EducationAmendmentBill772_9673_3.pdf |title= Education Amendment Bill – As reported from the Education and Science Committee |publisher= New Zealand Parliament |accessdate= June 26, 2013}}{{dead link|date=July 2013}}</ref> The Charter School model was heavily criticized by a wide range of educational authorities, teacher organizations, the general public and political parties who vowed to overturn it.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stuart|first1=Lynda|title=Charter schools: the case against|url=https://thespinoff.co.nz/society/18-05-2017/charter-schools-the-case-against/|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[The Spinoff]]|date=18 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Charter schools: an update|url=http://ppta.org.nz/dmsdocument/207|publisher=[[Post Primary Teachers' Association]]|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref><ref name="Interest Election 2017">{{cite news|last1=Wiener|first1=Julia|title=Election 2017 - Party Policies - Education - Charter Schools|url=https://www.interest.co.nz/news/87419/election-2017-party-policies-education-charter-schools|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=Interest.co.nz|date=27 March 2017}}</ref>
In late October 2017, the newly-formed [[Sixth Labour Government of New Zealand|Labour-led coalition government]] announced that it would be abolishing charter schools.<ref name="NZ Herald Oct 2017">{{cite news|last1=Collins|first1=Simon|title=Labour's education plans revealed: Primary school league tables axed, big NCEA shakeup|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11937975|accessdate=1 November 2017|publisher=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=30 October 2017}}</ref> This announcement triggered mixed responses with teaching unions supporting the Government while charter schools and the opposition National and ACT parties opposing the announcement.<ref name="PPTA March 2018">{{cite web|last1=Robinson|first1=Liz|title=Charter school removal a great day for students, teachers and parents|url=http://ppta.org.nz/news-and-media/charter-school-removal-a-great-day-for-students-teachers-and-parents/|publisher=Post Primary Teachers' Association|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref><ref name="Herald 7 March 2018">{{cite news|last1=Collins|first1=Simon|title=Charter schools at odds over Chris Hipkins' plans to abolish them|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12006267|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[New Zealand Herald]]|date=7 March 2018}}</ref><ref name="Nikki Kaye Stuff">{{cite news|last1=Walters|first1=Laura|title=National complains to Auditor-General about Government's handling of partnership school issue|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/101608899/national-complains-to-auditorgeneral-about-governments-handling-of-partnership-school-issue|accessdate=8 March 2018|agency=[[Stuff.co.nz]]|date=20 February 2018}}</ref> In response to protests, Prime Minister Ardern and the Māori Labour MPs Education Minister [[Kelvin Davis (politician)|Kelvin Davis]] and [[Willie Jackson (politician)|Willie Jackson]] have suggested that charter schools could convert to "special character" schools.<ref name="NZ Herald 8 March 2018">{{cite news|last1=Trevett|first1=Claire|title=PM says compromise will help charter schools to convert rather than close|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11992994|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[New Zealand Herald]]|date=12 February 2018}}</ref><ref name="RNZ 14 Feb 2018">{{cite news|last1=Boynton|first1=John|title=Māori charter schools safe - Labour's Māori MPs|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/te-manu-korihi/350396/maori-charter-schools-safe-labour-s-maori-mps|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date=14 February 2018}}</ref>
==Organizational structure and oversight== Partnership Schools in New Zealand come under the oversight of an independent Authorisation Board, appointed by the [[Minister of Education (New Zealand)|Minister of Education]]. The Board advises the Minister on which applications should be considered for contracts. The Board is also responsible for monitoring the educational performance and achievement progress of the Partnership Schools.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/about-us/|website=Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua Authorisation Board|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref> On 22 February 2018 the Authorisation Board's chair Catherine Isaac announced that the entire Authorisation Board would be resigning in protest of the [[Sixth Labour Government of New Zealand|Labour-led coalition government]]'s decision to abolish the Partnership School model.<ref name="Stuff 22 Feb 18">{{cite news|last1=Redmond|first1=Adele|title=Entire charter schools authorisation board to step down in protest|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/education/101685289/entire-charter-schools-board-to-step-down-in-protest|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[Stuff.co.nz]]|date=22 February 2018}}</ref>
===List of Partnership Schools=== As of March 2018, there are ten partnership schools in New Zealand.<ref>{{cite web|title=Find a School|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/find-a-school/|website=Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref>
*[[Middle School West Auckland]], sponsored by the [[Villa Education Trust]], opened February 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Middle School West Auckland|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/find-a-school/middle-school-west-auckland/|website=Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref> *[[Pacific Advance Senior School]], [[Auckland]], sponsored by the [[Pacific Peoples Advancement Trust]], opened February 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pacific Advance Senior School|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/find-a-school/pacific-advance-senior-school/|website=Partnership Schools/Kua Hourua|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref> *[[South Auckland Middle School]], sponsored by the Villa Education Trust, opened February 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=South Auckland Middle School|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/find-a-school/south-auckland-middle-school/|website=Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref> *[[Te Aratika Academy]], [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]], sponsored by the [[Te Aratika Charitable Trust]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Te Aratika Academy|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/find-a-school/te-aratika-academy/|website=Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref> *[[Te Kura Hourua O Whangarei Terenga Paraoa]], [[Whangarei]], sponsored by the [[He Puna Marama Charitable Trust]], opened February 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Te Kura Hourua O Whangarei Terenga Paraoa|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/find-a-school/te-kura-hourua-o-whangarei-terenga-paraoa/|website=Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref> *[[Te Kura Māori o Waatea]], Auckland, sponsored by the [[Manukau Urban Māori Authority]], opened February 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Te Kura Māori o Waatea|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/find-a-school/te-kura-maori-o-waatea/|website=Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref> *[[Te Kāpehu Whetū (Teina)]], Whangarei, sponsored by the He Puna Marama Charitable Trust, opened February 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Te Kāpehu Whetū (Teina)|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/find-a-school/te-kapehu-whetu-teina/|website=Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref> *[[Te Kōpuku High]], [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]], sponsored by the [[Kia Ata Mai Educational Trust]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Te Kōpuku High|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/find-a-school/te-kopuku-high/|website=Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref> *[[The Rise UP Academy]], Auckland, sponsored by [[The Rise UP Trust]], opened February 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Rise UP Academy|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/find-a-school/the-rise-up-academy/|website=Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref> *[[Vanguard Military School]], Auckland, sponsored by the [[Advanced Trading Group Ltd.]], opened February 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vanguard Military School|url=http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/find-a-school/vanguard-military-school/|website=Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua|accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref>
==History== ===Origins=== In 1989, the [[Fourth Labour Government of New Zealand|Fourth Labour Government]] reformed the state (public) school system in what was known as the "Tomorrow's Schools" reforms. Blaming the amount of centralised bureaucracy for slipping school standards, the government disestablished the Department of Education, replacing it with the smaller [[Ministry of Education (New Zealand)|Ministry of Education]] and moving the governance of state schools to their individual school communities.<ref>{{cite report |first= Mark |last= Adams |date= January 2009 |title= Tomorrow’s schools Today: New Zealand’s Experiment 20 years on |url= http://mercatus.org/sites/default/files/publication/WP0901_GAP_New_Zealand_Reforms.pdf |publisher= Mercatus Center, [[George Mason University]] |accessdate= 23 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Butterworth|first1=Graham|last2=Butterwoth|first2=Susan|title=Reforming Education: The New Zealand Experience, 1984-1996|date=1998|publisher=Dunmore Press|location=[[Palmerston North]]|isbn=0864693346|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books/about/Reforming_Education.html?id=V0HMAAAACAAJ&redir_esc=y|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref> Since the [[Education Act 1877]], the New Zealand public primary schooling system has been free and secular with provision for private religious schools. In 1935, secondary school education was made free by the [[First Labour Government of New Zealand|First Labour Government]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=King|first1=Michael|title=The Penguin History of New Zealand|date=2003|publisher=Penguin Group (NZ)|location=North Shore, Auckland|isbn=9780143018674|pages=233-234, 356|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books/about/The_Penguin_History_of_New_Zealand.html?id=LKQP2sw_BVoC&redir_esc=y|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref> State schools are [[crown entity|crown entities]], meaning they are government-owned and retain the strong governmental and parliamentary oversight and control in common with other New Zealand crown entities. State schools are the most common in New Zealand.<ref name="NZ Schooling System">{{cite web|title=The school system|url=https://www.newzealandnow.govt.nz/living-in-nz/education/school-system#section--1|website=New Zealand Now|publisher=[[Immigration New Zealand]]|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref>
Apart from the numerous State schools there are several variations on the Tomorrow's Schools model, the largest of which is [[state-integrated schools]]. State-integrated schools are parochial schools or private schools that have been "integrated" into the state school system under the Private Schools Conditional Integration Act 1975,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.legislation.co.nz/act/public/1975/0129/latest/contents.html# |title=Private Schools Conditional Integration Act 1975 |access-date=2013-08-04 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130223214652/http://www.legislation.co.nz/act/public/1975/0129/latest/contents.html# |archive-date=2013-02-23 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> usually because they have run into financial difficulty. These schools are run the same as state schools, but they are allowed to retain their special character. Proprietors of the school (e.g. the Catholic Church in the case of a Catholic school) own the integrated school facilities and sit on the school's board of trustees, but they do not receive government funds to maintain [[separation of church and state]], and subsequently require parents to pay "attendance dues" for upkeep of the facilities.<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Donnell|first1=Susan|title=The Character and Culture of the Catholic School|date=2001|publisher=New Zealand Council for Education Research|location=Wellington|isbn=1877140988|pages=43-69|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=sFIUAgAACAAJ&dq=the+character+and+culture+of+the+catholic+school&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjJjOCdu97ZAhUCerwKHYhWDU4Q6AEIJzAA|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Sweetman|first1=Rory|title=A Fair and Just Solution?: A History of the Integration of Private Schools in New Zealand|date=2002|publisher=Dunmore Press in association with the Ministry of Culture and Heritage|location=Palmerston North|isbn=0864694148|pages=13-22|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=3197124|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref><ref name="NZ Schooling System" /> [[Kura Kaupapa schools]] are state run schools with heavy emphasis on learning [[Maori language]] and [[Maori culture|culture]] but having most of the features of normal state schools.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Calman|first1=Ross|title='Māori education – mātauranga - Kaupapa Māori education'|url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/maori-education-matauranga/page-5|publisher=Te Ara - the Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref><ref name="School types">{{cite web|title=Different types of secondary schools|url=https://parents.education.govt.nz/secondary-school/secondary-schooling-in-nz/different-types-of-secondary-schools/|publisher=[[Ministry of Education (New Zealand)|Ministry of Education]]|accessdate=9 March 2018}}</ref> In addition there are fee paying private schools which receive limited funding from the state. Most follow the national curriculum or internationally recognized variations.<ref name="NZ Schooling System" /><ref name="School types" />
===Legislative implementation=== Following the [[New Zealand general election, 2011|2011 general election]], the National Party, in return for [[confidence and supply]], announced it would pick up an [[ACT New Zealand|ACT party]] policy of setting up charter schools in southern Auckland and eastern Christchurch within three years. This followed the appointment of Lesley Longstone as the new Secretary of Education, who had experience in England with charter schools, although Longstone resigned in November 2012 after falling out with Education Minister [[Hekia Parata]] over the error-ridden [[Novopay]] payroll system. The National-ACT alliance intended to set up charter schools as alternatives to state schools. Schools would be operated by private [[business]]es or organisations and would be directly accountable for performance to the organizations running them. The schools would receive state funding and private donations, but have the same freedoms as private schools in matters such as in setting the curriculum, length of the school year and teachers' pay. Teaching staff would also not have to be registered or even formally trained (although they would still require police clearance). Charter schools would still be subject to triennial external reviews by ERO, and the government would still have the power to intervene if there are serious problems, either taking over from the sponsor for a period of time or sacking them altogether.<ref>{{cite news |first= Derek |last= Cheng |date= December 6, 2011 |title= What are charter schools? |newspaper=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |location= Auckland |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/election-2011/news/article.cfm?c_id=1503012&objectid=10771267 |accessdate= January 21, 2012}}</ref> Unlike state schools, charter schools would not be subject to either [[Office of the Ombudsman (New Zealand)|Ombudsman]] scrutiny or the [[Official Information Act 1982]]. However, in April 2013, it was also announced that charter schools would be subject to Ombudsman scrutiny on matters relating to suspensions and expulsions (other than the Ombudsman, the only other way to appeal a suspension or expulsion is through the court system).
The plan was heavily criticised by the opposition [[New Zealand Labour Party|Labour]] and [[Green Party of Aotearoa New Zealand|Green]] parties, and the main teachers' professional associations—the [[New Zealand Educational Institute|NZEI]] and the [[Post Primary Teachers' Association|PPTA]]. Most of the opposition was over the idea of unregistered and untrained teachers having direct contact with students, and the lack of accountability through the Ombudsman and the Official Information Act. In April 2012, [[Massey University]] released a report highly critical of the proposed charter school model, claiming there was no international evidence to support claims that charter schools do better and all they would do is increase segregation.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Charter-schools-make-things-worse---study/tabid/423/articleID/250288/Default.aspx |title= Charter schools make things worse - study |publisher= [[3 News New Zealand]] |date= April 13, 2012 |accessdate= June 22, 2013}}</ref> In September 2012, Minister of Education [[Hekia Parata]] announced that many schools in Christchurch would be closed or amalgamated, largely due to population changes and damaged facilities following the [[2011 Christchurch earthquake|February 2011 earthquake]]. However, parents, teachers and students protested at the changes for going too far, and feared that the closures were being used as an excuse to start charter schools. In June 2013, the closed school sites were put up for sale, with charter schools and property development among the proposed uses.<ref>{{cite book |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/education/8748364/Shuttered-Chch-schools-to-be-in-demand |title=Shuttered Chch schools to be in demand |author= McDonald, Liz |work= stuff.co.nz|date=June 3, 2013}}</ref>
The Education Amendment Bill to allow charter schools, rebranded Partnership Schools/''Kura Hourua'', was introduced on 15 October 2012 and passed its first reading three days later 63 votes to 56. The bill was referred to the Education and Science [[select committee]] for closer scrutiny and public submissions, with the committee reporting back in April 2013 that the bill should proceed with amendments.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.parliament.nz/en-NZ/PB/Legislation/Bills/6/1/7/00DBHOH_BILL11822_1-Education-Amendment-Bill.htm |title= Education Amendment Bill – Bills – Legislation |publisher= New Zealand Parliament |date= October 18, 2012 |accessdate= January 27, 2013}}</ref> After the report was released, [[United Future]] MP Peter Dunne announced he was pulling support for charter schools, leaving only the National, Act and Maori Parties supporting the bill.<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.3news.co.nz/Dunne-against-charter-schools/tabid/1607/articleID/294742/Default.aspx|work=3 News NZ |title= Dunne against charter schools| date=April 18, 2013}}</ref> The bill passed its third reading on 4 June 2013, 62 votes to 57. During the select committee stage, the Labour Party announced that if elected to government at the 2014 general election, it would introduce provisions to require charter schools to employ registered teachers and make the schools fully accountable to the Ombudsmen and the Official Information Act. It would also not allow any new charter schools and would not guarantee future funding or integration to any existing schools, leaving them either to continue as private schools or close altogether.<ref name="Education Amendment Bill" />
===Creation and operations=== In May 2013, the PPTA published in its staff newsletter a list of 21 parties it believed were interested in the charter school programme, which included a high proportion of religious groups.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/education/8698640/PPTA-outs-charter-school-hopefuls |title=PPTA outs charter school hopefuls |author= Shadwell, Talia |date=May 21, 2013 |work= stuff.co.nz}}</ref> While the Ministry of Education refused to release the full list of 36 interested parties, in July 2013, the Ombudsman overruled the MoE and forced them to release the list as soon as possible.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10903240 |title= Ministry ordered to release names of charter school applicants |first= Kate |last= Shuttleworth |publisher= The New Zealand Herald |date= 25 July 2013 |accessdate= 26 July 2013}}</ref> In September 2013, the [[Minister of Education (New Zealand)|Education Minister]] [[Hekia Parata]] and Association Education Minister [[John Banks (New Zealand politician)|John Banks]] announced that the first five charter schools would open in [[Auckland]] and [[Northland Region|Northland]] by the first term of 2014. These schools included the [[Vanguard Military School]], the Māori secondary schools [[Te Kura Hourua o Whangarei Terenga Paraoa]] and [[Te Kura Hourua ki Whangaruru]], [[The Rise UP Academy]], and the Christian-oriented [[South Auckland Middle School]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Davison|first1=Isaac|title=Five charter schools to open in 2014|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11125874|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[New Zealand Herald]]|date=17 September 2013}}</ref>
In September 2014, the Northland-based Te Kura Hourua ki Whangaruru in [[Whangaruru]] attracted controversy over its poor leadership, high absenteeism of 20%, and mismanagement of government funds. The school, which received 500% more funding than a state school, spent half its income buying a farm. The Ministry of Education carried out a secret inquiry and immediately installed its own manager. One of the two original managers left hurriedly. Problems first arose in 2013 when it was claimed that the school had been set up in a paddock using portaloos for toilets. It was reported that drugs were a problem in the school and that some students had been removed to an unknown place. The school has only one teacher with a current practicing certificate. The original management was replaced by an executive manager from [[Child, Youth and Family]]. The school received $27,000 per student compared to $6,000 per student in a state school.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ppta.org.nz/communities/president-page/3083-charter-school-quango# |title=PPTA News.Vol 35.p3. August 2014. A.Roberts |access-date=2014-09-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006124534/http://www.ppta.org.nz/communities/president-page/3083-charter-school-quango# |archive-date=2014-10-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/254084/charter-school-a-mess-principals|title=Charter school a mess - principals|first=Lois|last=Williams|publisher=Radio New Zealand|date=9 September 2014}}</ref> In October 2015, the Education Ministry acknowledged that charter schools had been over-funded an extra $888,000 more than they would have been allocated had their funding been strictly based on their enrolments.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gerritsen|first1=John|title=Ministry says charter schools "over-funding" is $888,000|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/287659/charter-schools-'over-funded'-by-$888,000|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date=22 October 2015}}</ref>
In May 2016, an independent Partnership School support entity called E Tipu E Rea was established to provide support for existing and prospective charter school sponsors through a $500,000 conditional grant from the Government. Education Under-secretary and ACT leader [[David Seymour (politician)|David Seymour]] claimed that this would bring NZ charter schools in line with overseas models such as [[England]]'s [[New Schools Network]] and [[New York City|New York]]'s [[New York Charter School Centre]]. The Board was chaired by former EY Australasia CEO Rob McLeod. Other board members included former [[Maori Party]] Co-Leader Dame [[Tariana Turia]], Dame Jenny Gibbs, former [[New Zealand national rugby union team|All Black]] rugby player [[La’auli Savae Michael Jones]], Bruce Ritchie, and Kep Rapson.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.voxy.co.nz/politics/5/252150|title=Independent entity to support Partnership Schools|website=Voxy.co.nz|date=May 20, 2016|access-date=May 2, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.education.govt.nz/ministry-of-education/information-releases/partnership-schools-kura-hourua-information-release/partnership-schools-policy-development-process/|title=Partnership Schools Policy Development|website=Education in New Zealand|language=en-NZ|access-date=2016-05-20}}</ref> In August 2016, Seymour announced that two new Māori-oriented charter schools would be opening in Hamilton and Napier by 2017, adding to the eight that were already operating.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Young|first1=Audrey|title=Two new charter schools approved for opening in 2017 in Hamilton and Napier|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11701952|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[New Zealand Herald]]|date=30 August 2016}}</ref>
In May 2017, the consultancy firm Martin Jenkins published an independent report on behalf of the Ministry of Education praising most of the country's eight charter schools for helping Māori, Pacific Islander, and disadvantaged children.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gerritsen|first1=John|title=NZ's charter schools given good report card|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/330165/nz's-charter-schools-given-good-report-card|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date=5 May 2017}}</ref> During the [[New Zealand general election, 2017|2017 general election]], the opposition Labour, Green, and [[New Zealand First]] parties announced that they would introduce legislation abolishing charter schools if elected into government.<ref name="Interest Election 2017" /> On 7 September, the National Government announced the creation of four new charter schools including a Christchurch outpost of the Auckland-based [[Vanguard Military School]], a Māori-oriented junior high school, a bilingual Māori high school, and a [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics|STEM]]-oriented Auckland school.<ref>{{cite news|title=Four new charter schools announced by govt|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/338911/four-new-charter-schools-announced-by-govt|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date=7 September 2017}}</ref>
===Proposed abolition=== Following the formation of a [[Sixth Labour Government of New Zealand|Labour-led coalition government]] in October 2017, the new Education Minister [[Chris Hipkins]] announced that the Government would be abolishing charter schools.<ref name="NZ Herald Oct 2017" /> In early 2018, the Labour-led Government introduced legislation blocking the creation of future charter schools while still allowing the existing 11 charter schools to continue operating while they negotiated options with the Ministry of Education.<ref>{{cite news|title=Early end on cards for charter schools|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/political/349965/early-end-on-cards-for-charter-schools|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date=8 February 2018}}</ref> The Government's announcement was welcomed by the Post Primary Teachers' Association.<ref name="PPTA March 2018" /> By contrast, the announcement was criticized by charter schools, several parents, and the opposition National and ACT parties.<ref name="Herald 7 March 2018" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Charter schools: Minister has a fight on his hands|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/350063/charter-schools-minister-has-a-fight-on-his-hands|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date=12 February 2018}}</ref> The National Party's education spokesperson [[Nikki Kaye]] asked the [[Controller and Auditor-General of New Zealand|Auditor-General]] to investigate potential conflicts of interest in the process of closing charter schools.<ref name="Nikki Kaye Stuff" />
On 11 February 2018, ACT leader and charter school advocate David Seymour led a 150-strong protest in Central Auckland criticizing the Government's decision.<ref>{{cite news|title=Protesters supporting charter schools gather in Auckland|url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/home/politics/2018/02/protesters-supporting-charter-schools-gather-in-auckland.html|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[Newshub]]|date=11 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Furley|first1=Tom|title=Charter school protest: 'This ain't anywhere near the end of this'|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/350153/charter-school-protest-this-ain-t-anywhere-near-the-end-of-this|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date=11 February 2018}}</ref> In response to criticism from parents and charter school advocates, Prime Minister Ardern and the Māori Labour MPs Education Minister [[Kelvin Davis (politician)|Kelvin Davis]] and former broadcaster [[Willie Jackson (politician)|Willie Jackson]] have suggested that charter schools could convert to "special character" schools in order to avoid closure.<ref name="NZ Herald 8 March 2018" /><ref name="RNZ 14 Feb 2018" /> On 21 February the entire Partnership Schools Authorisation Board announced that it would be resigning in protest of the Government's approach to abolishing charter schools.<ref name="Stuff 22 Feb 18" /> On 5 March, charter school representatives including Villa Education Trust's academic advisor Alwyn Poole sought clarification from the Government on the deadline for charter schools to convert to "special character" schools. Education Ministry spokesperson Katrina Casey issued a statement confirming that 1 April 2018 would be the deadline for new schools but not existing schools.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Patterson|first1=Jane|title=Charter schools seeking clarification around deadline confusion|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/351943/charter-schools-seeking-clarification-around-deadline-confusion|accessdate=8 March 2018|publisher=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date=6 March 2018}}</ref>
On 2 April 2018, the ''[[New Zealand Herald]]'' newspaper reported that the Government had paid NZ$3.4 million to five proposed charter schools on the day that the Labour-led coalition government was sworn in on 26 October 2017. Education Minister Chris Hipkins acknowledged that his Government had paid the schools establishment grants since the Government was bound by contracts signed before the 2017 general election. None of these proposed schools have paid back the establishment grants since they are in the process of negotiating with the Government about reopening as state schools or integrated schools. It was also reported that terminating the contracts for the existing 11 charter schools and proposed five charter schools would generate compensation costs of up to NZ$1 million per school; amounting to an estimated total of NZ$16 million. These proposed schools have included the science-oriented City Senior School in Auckland, Vanguard Military School's Christchurch branch, the Gisborne Māori high school Te Rūnanga o Tūranganui ā Kiwa, and Waatea High School.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Collins|first1=Simon|title=Charter schools that may never open were paid $3.4m|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12024614|accessdate=12 April 2018|publisher=[[New Zealand Herald]]|date=3 April 2018}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Education in New Zealand]] *[[History of education in New Zealand]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs=
<ref name=nh-2011>{{cite web |date=8 December 2011 |title=What are charter schools? |website=Newshub |accessdate=20 October 2017 |url=http://www.newshub.co.nz/nznews/what-are-charter-schools-2011120814 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171019183200/http://www.newshub.co.nz/nznews/what-are-charter-schools-2011120814 |archivedate=20 October 2017 }}</ref>
}}
==External links== *[http://www.minedu.govt.nz/theMinistry/EducationInitiatives/PartnershipSchools.aspx Partnership Schools | Kura Hourua] at the Ministry of Education *[http://partnershipschools.education.govt.nz/ Partnership Schools/Kura Hourua Authorisation Board] [[Category:Education in New Zealand]] [[Category:Charter schools|New Zealand]]

revision.text:
{{merge to|Alcohol use among college students|date=September 2018}} {{globalize/US|date=January 2014}} <!-- Talk before proposing deletion please. --> The rates of college students binge drinking in the United States have fluctuated for the past years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=184462 |title=JAMA Network | JAMA | College Binge Drinking Still on the Rise |publisher=Jama.jamanetwork.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> As high as 40% of college students could now be considered alcoholics, as defined by the next edition psychiatry's diagnostic manual, but many of these individuals would be regarded as having only a mild drinking problem. Most college binge drinkers and drug users don't develop lifelong problems.<ref>{{cite web|last=Szalavitz |first=Maia |url=http://healthland.time.com/2012/05/14/dsm-5-could-mean-40-of-college-students-are-alcoholics/ |title=DSM-5 Could Categorize 40% of College Students as Alcoholics | TIME.com |publisher=Healthland.time.com |date=2012-05-14 |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sanderson |first=Megan |url=http://dailyemerald.com/2012/05/22/redefining-alcoholic-what-this-means-for-students/ |title=About 37 percent of college students could now be considered alcoholics | Emerald Media |publisher=Dailyemerald.com |date=2012-05-22 |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref>
==Social stigma== [[National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism]] (NIAAA) reported in 2012, that more than 80% of college students drink alcohol, with estimated 40% report binge drinking in the past 2 weeks, and about 25% report having academic consequences because of their drinking.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pubs.niaaa.nih.gov/publications/CollegeFactSheet/CollegeFactSheet.pdf |title=College Drinking |publisher=Pubs.niaaa.nih.gov |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> 56% of students reported binge drinking once a week.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dodd, L.J., Al-Nakeeb, Y., Nevill, A. and Forshaw, M.J., 2010|first=|date=|title=Lifestyle risk factors of students: a cluster analytical approach|url=|journal=Preventative medicine|volume=51 |issue=1|pages=73–77.|via=}}</ref> In comparison, the comparable figure of alcoholism for American Indian and Alaskan Native youth ("Native youth" hereafter) is approximately 80 percent (Beauvais, Oetting, & Wolf, 1989).
==Factors== Individual and environmental factors for experiencing alcohol-related consequences have been identified such as drinking during high-risk periods, such as spring break, or belonging to specific student subgroups (e.g., Greek organizations).<ref>{{cite journal|title= An Update of Research Examining College Student Alcohol-Related Consequences: New Perspectives and Implications for Interventions|date=2013-03-25 |pmid=23241024 | doi=10.1111/acer.12031 |volume=37 |pmc=3601564 |journal=Alcohol Clin Exp Res |pages=709–16 | last1 = Mallett | first1 = KA | last2 = Varvil-Weld | first2 = L | last3 = Borsari | first3 = B | last4 = Read | first4 = JP | last5 = Neighbors | first5 = C | last6 = White | first6 = HR}}</ref> Drinking throughout high school also played a role, suggesting that binge drinking starts earlier than college for some.<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.2105/AJPH.85.7.921 | volume=85 | title=Correlates of college student binge drinking. | journal=American Journal of Public Health | pages=921–926| pmc=1615519 }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Alcohol use among college students]] * [[Alcohol advertising on college campuses]] * [[American Indian alcoholism]] * [[Cigarette smoking among college students]] * [[Pregaming]]
==References== {{reflist|liststyle=}}7. Dodd, L.J., Al-Nakeeb, Y., Nevill, A. and Forshaw, M.J., 2010. Lifestyle risk factors of students: a cluster analytical approach. ''Preventive medicine'', ''51''(1), pp. 73–77.
[[Category:Student culture]] [[Category:Alcohol]]

{{Infobox company | name = Connections Academy | logo = ConnectionsAcademyLogo.jpg | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | trading_name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. For multiple names in different languages, use {{Lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | romanized_name = | former_name = | type = | traded_as = | ISIN = | ISIN2 = | industry = [[education management organization]] | genre = | predecessor = <!-- or: | predecessors = --> | successor = <!-- or: | successors = --> | founded = {{Start date and age|2001}} | founder = Barbara Dreyer | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hq_location = 1001 Fleet Street, 5th Floor | hq_location_city = [[Baltimore, Maryland]] | hq_location_country = | num_locations = | num_locations_year = <!-- Year of num_locations data (if known) --> | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = | products = | brands = | production = | production_year = <!-- Year of production data (if known) --> | services = | revenue = | revenue_year = <!-- Year of revenue data (if known) --> | operating_income = | income_year = <!-- Year of operating_income data (if known) --> | net_income = <!-- or: | profit = --> | net_income_year = <!-- or: | profit_year = --><!-- Year of net_income/profit data (if known) --> | aum = <!-- Only for financial-service companies --> | assets = | assets_year = <!-- Year of assets data (if known) --> | equity = | equity_year = <!-- Year of equity data (if known) --> | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | members = | members_year = <!-- Year of members data (if known) --> | num_employees = | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = [[Pearson Education]] | divisions = | subsid = | module = <!-- Used to embed other templates --> | website = {{URL|connectionsacademy.com}} | footnotes = | intl = <!-- Set positively ("true"/"yes"/etc) if company is international, otherwise omit --> }}
'''Connections Academy''' provides online school products and services to virtual schools for grades K-12, including full-time online schools bearing the "Connections Academy" name across the country. It is based in Columbia, Maryland<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://patch.com/maryland/columbia/pearson-opens-new-office-downtown-columbia|title=Pearson Opens New Office in Downtown Columbia|date=2017-12-07|work=Columbia, MD Patch|access-date=2018-04-04|language=en-US}}</ref> and is part of [[Pearson plc|Pearson's]] Online & Blended Learning K-12 group. It supports public online schools for grades K-12 across the United States. A private online school, International Connections Academy,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/expat/2016/01/20/do-the-math-the-percentage-of-expat-homeschoolers-is-growing/|title=Do the Math: The Percentage of Expat Homeschoolers Is Growing|last=Mitic|first=Ginanne Brownell|newspaper=WSJ|access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> is also available to students who live abroad. Online schools are an alternative to traditional public schools.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thejournal.com/articles/2011/07/26/competing-for-the-virtual-student.aspx|title=Competing for the Virtual Student -- THE Journal|website=THE Journal|access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> Similar to charter schools, they are subsidized by the state. Although they contract with many non-profit schools, they are not a non-profit organization.<ref>{{cite web|title = Connections Academy- Homeschooling Resources|url = http://www.homeschool.com/resources/ConnectionsAcademy/|date = |accessdate = 15 September 2015|publisher = Homeschool.com}}</ref>
==History== In the spring of 2001, Sylvan Ventures started a separate business unit to create a virtual school program with its first virtual schools beginning in Wisconsin and Colorado.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.wsfa.com/story/36719023/schools-of-the-future-inside-alabamas-virtual-public-school|title=Schools of the future: Inside Alabama's virtual public school|last=Henry|first=Bryan|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en}}</ref> The company first began providing online school services to two schools in the fall of 2002. In September 2004, Connections Academy was sold to an investor group led by [[Apollo Global Management|Apollo Management, L.P.]] The company now operates public schools under management contracts from charter schools or school districts.
A new corporate entity called Connections Education was established in early 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Multinational giant set to run first virtual school in Maine|url=http://www.pressherald.com/2014/03/16/real_giant_set_to_run_first_virtual_school_in_maine_/|website = The Portland Press Herald / Maine Sunday Telegram|accessdate = 2015-09-16|first=Tom|last=Bell }}</ref> In this same year, on September 15, 2011, [[Pearson PLC|Pearson]], an international learning company, acquired Connections Education for in excess of $400 million.<ref name="acquisition">[http://www.connectionsacademy.com/news/pearson-acquisition.aspx Connections Academy], retrieved 2012-08-01</ref>
Connections Education consists of two education-focused divisions including Connections Academy and Pearson Online & Blended Learning that serves educational institutions and other organizations with online learning solutions.
In October 2017, Alabama became the 34th state to partner with Connection Academy.<ref name=":0" />
In December 2017, it was announced that one Connections Academy school's contract would not be renewed and the decision is under appeal. <ref>http://aae.ped.state.nm.us/docs/1617/SchoolGrading/554_001_STATE_CHARTER_NM_CONNECTIONS_ACADEMY__SchoolGrading_2017.pdf</ref>
== Awards == 2015 & 2016 awards include: * USDLA "Outstanding Leadership in the Field of Distance Learning" 2016 awarded to Amada Ebel, Executive Director, South Carolina Connections Academy<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2016/05/prweb13403741.htm|title=USDLA 2016 International Awards Presented for Excellence in Distance Learning for Individuals, Organizations and Companies Honoring their Outstanding Achievements|newspaper=PRWeb|access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> * Ohio Connections Academy recognized with a 2015 Momentum Award by Ohio State Board of Education, 2016<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://education.ohio.gov/Topics/School-Improvement/Awards-and-Recognition/Momentum-Award|title=Ohio Department of Education|last=|first=|date=|website=Ohio Department of Education|publisher=|access-date=October 11, 2016}}</ref> * Indiana Connections Academy Recognized for Counseling Program, 2015<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.schoolcounselor.org/school-counselors-members/ramp/ramp-recipients|title=RAMP Recipients {{!}} American School Counselor Association (ASCA)|website=www.schoolcounselor.org|access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> * Lea Ann Lockard, Executive Director of Texas Connections Academy @ Houston, EdTech Leadership Award, 2016<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://edtechdigest.wordpress.com/2016/03/15/2016-finalists/|title=2016 – Finalists & Winners|last=victorrivero|date=2016-03-15|website=edtechdigest.com|access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> * Dr. Patricia Hoge, Connections Education Executive Vice President of Curriculum and Instruction and Chief Academic Officer, USDLA Award for Outstanding Leadership by an Individual in the Field of Distance Learning, 2015<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.connectionsacademy.com/news/ce-wins-usdla-awards-2015|title=Connections Education wins International Distance Learning Awards|website=www.connectionsacademy.com|access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> * Connections Education Named "Top Workplace" by ''The Baltimore Sun'' for third consecutive year, 2015<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://marketplace.baltimoresun.com/baltimore-md-features/special-section/Top-Workplaces/12-06-2015/Page-25/Story/NO-9-Connections-Education|title=Top Workplaces - Page 25 - NO .9 Connections Education|website=marketplace.baltimoresun.com|access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> * Connections Education Awarded Renewed AdvancED Accreditation, 2015<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.connectionsacademy.com/news/advanced-accreditation-renewal|title=Connections Education Awarded Renewed AdvancED Accreditation|website=www.connectionsacademy.com|access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> * Connections Education's Connexus® education management system, GradPoint, and education technology online learning courses Win Tech&Learning Award of Excellence for Best Upgraded Products, 2015<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2015/10/prweb13034119.htm|title=Pearson Leads the 2015 Tech & Learning Magazine Awards of Excellence With Nine Winners|newspaper=PRWeb|access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> * Connections Education Wins Three BESSIE Awards for Exemplary Educational Software, 2015<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://computedgazette.com/page3.html|title=ComputED Gazette - 2016 BESSIE Awards|website=computedgazette.com|access-date=2016-10-11}}</ref> * Connections Education Middle School Art Wins CODiE Award—Honored in Best Arts & Creativity Solution category, 2015<ref>connectionsacademy.com/news/ce-wins-bcb-award-2018</ref>

{{Orphan|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Conversocial | logo = Conversocial Logo.png | logo_size = 225px | type = Private | founded = 2009 | founder = Joshua March | location_city = New York City, USA
London, UK | industry = Software | homepage = [http://conversocial.com conversocial.com] }} '''Conversocial''' is a provider of social customer service software headquartered in [[New York City]] and founded in [[London]]. Companies such as [[Google]], [[Barclaycard]], [[Hertz]], [[Tesco]], Sainsbury's, [[Volkswagen]] and [[University of Phoenix]] use Conversocial's [[Software as a Service]] to manage the flow of customer service inquiries and discussions on social media channels such as [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]], [[Google+]], [[Instagram]] and [[YouTube]].{{citation needed|date=November 2013}} == History == Joshua March founded Conversocial in November 2009 in London. After spending two years working with applications for social media for both the Facebook Developer Garage London and iPlatform, he realized that social media was the future of communications online.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/blog/2012/sep/27/iplatform-bought-betapond|title=iPlatform bought by social media marketing company Betapond|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=25 April 2013|location=London|first=Jemima|last=Kiss|date=27 September 2012}} After iPlatform, which they sold to social media marketing company Betapond in 2012, March has focused solely on Conversocial. In February 2016, [[Twitter]] announced that Conversocial is a Twitter Official Partner, and is working with the company to add deep messaging deep links to tweets.{{Cite web|url=https://blog.twitter.com/2016/making-customer-service-even-better-on-twitter|title=Making customer service even better on Twitter|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} In February 2017, Twitter announced that would deepen its partnership with Conversocial for greater growth and monetization in the area of social customer service.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1418091/000156459017001236/twtr-ex991_8.htm|title=Twitter Q4 and Fiscal Year 2016 Shareholder Letter|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == Funding == Since Conversocial’s public launch at Tempero (now [http://icuc.social/en-EMEA icuc.social]) in 2010, they’ve released their Enterprise edition and raised a total of $23.96 million in funding.{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/conversocial#/entity|title=Crunchbase Conversocial|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} In 2012 Conversocial expanded to the USA, opening its headquarters in Manhattan, New York.{{Cite web|url=http://diginomica.com/2015/11/04/debating-the-effectiveness-of-social-customer-service-with-conversocials-joshua-march/|title=Debating the effectiveness of social customer service – with Conversocial’s Joshua March|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{cite web|last=Mott|first=Nathaniel|title=Conversocial Raises $1.25M and Moves to New York to Turn Bitchy Tweets into Customer Service Opportunities|url=http://pandodaily.com/2012/09/04/conversocial-raises-1-25m-and-moves-to-new-york-to-turn-bitchy-tweets-into-customer-service-opportunities/|work=September 4, 2012|publisher=Pandodaily|accessdate=25 April 2013}} In 2013,Conversocial received $4.4 million in additional funding from a round led by Octopus Ventures.{{cite web|last=Crook|first=Jordan|title=Conversocial CRM Social Media Tool Raises $4.4M Led By Octopus Investments|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/05/28/conversocial-crm-social-media-tool-raises-4-4m-led-by-octopus-investments/|work=|date=May 28, 2013|publisher=TechCrunch|accessdate=13 June 2013}} In 2014,Conversocial received $5 million in additional funding from a round led by Octopus Ventures.{{Cite web|title = Conversocial Receives Additional $5M in Series A2 Funding|url = http://www.finsmes.com/2014/07/conversocial-receives-additional-5m-in-series-a2-funding.html|website = FinSMEs|date = 2014-07-16|access-date = 2016-02-16}} In 2015,Conversocial received $11 million in additional funding from a round led by Dawn Capital.{{Cite news|title = Conversocial Raises $11 Million to Fuel Continued Growth and Innovation|url = https://www.reuters.com/article/ny-conversocial-idUSnBw196693a+100+BSW20151019|newspaper = Reuters|date = 2015-10-19|access-date = 2016-02-16}} == Product == Conversocial is a real-time social media management system which allows companies to provide customer support through Facebook and Twitter. Conversocial's functions include: * Priority Response Engine – The self-learning prioritization engine uses natural language processing and analysis of historic responses to prioritise messages. * Conversation History * Team Management – Conversocial's collaborative platform lets teams share social communication, while management retains control of social platforms. * Analytics & Reporting – Measures important data such as customer satisfaction, agent response times, and issue frequency. == Leadership == CEO Joshua March has appeared on [[CNBC]],{{cite web|last=March|first=Joshua|title=Customer Service Through Social Media|url=http://video.cnbc.com/gallery/?video=3000097970|work=June 26, 2012|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=25 April 2013}} [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]],{{cite news|last=March|first=Joshua|title=Should Social Media Sites Apologize for False Info?|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/should-social-media-sites-apologize-for-false-info-G5JaH404SYWs_jiQXiwL8Q.html|work=April 22, 2013|publisher=Bloomberg TV|accessdate=25 April 2013}}{{cite news|last=March|first=Joshua|title=Social media is Changing the Way We Complain|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/social-media-is-changing-the-way-we-complain-jxpqqa91T5ejiTv4bDcp4Q.html|work=April 25, 2013|publisher=Bloomberg TV|accessdate=25 April 2013}}{{cite news|last=March|first=Joshua|title=How Complaints On Twitter Spook Retailers|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/retailers-are-cashing-in-on-social-media-8xPqc_r4Ri~I2ek9iPqSDA.html|work=December 20, 2012|publisher=Bloomberg TV|accessdate=25 April 2013}}{{cite news|last=March|first=Joshua|title=Capitalizing On Social Media Shoppers|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/video/capitalizing-on-social-media-shoppers-vVg8_ytSTc2A~myxtstNXg.html|work=November 26, 2012|publisher=Bloomberg TV|accessdate=25 April 2013}} [[Fox Business]],{{cite web|last=March|first=Joshua|title=Has Twitter Gotten Too Big Too Fast?|url=http://video.foxbusiness.com/v/2322474862001/has-twitter-gotten-too-big-too-fast/|work=April 23, 2013|publisher=Fox Business|accessdate=25 April 2013}} and BBC as a commentator on customer service and social media, and was named one of 2012’s Top 10 Hottest Digital Marketers by iMedia Connection.{{cite web|last=Editors|first=iMedia Connection|title=iMedia's Top 10 Hottest Digital Marketers of 2012 |url=http://www.imediaconnection.com/content/32469.asp|work=August 21, 2012|publisher=iMedia Connection|accessdate=25 April 2013}} Josh March frequently writes about social media and customer service, and his work has been featured in numerous business and technology publications.{{cite web|last=March|first=Joshua|title=Why social makes customer service more important than ever|url=http://pandodaily.com/2013/04/20/why-social-makes-customer-service-matter-like-never-before/|work=April 20, 2013|publisher=Pandodaily|accessdate=25 April 2013}}{{cite web|last=March|first=Joshua|title=How To Integrate Social Customer Service Into Your Marketing Strategy|url=http://www.cmo.com/content/cmo-com/home/articles/2012/12/14/how_to_integrate_soc.html|work=December 14, 2012|publisher=CMO|accessdate=25 April 2013}}{{cite web|last=March|first=Joshua|title=Customer Service Is Your Marketing Strategy|url=http://chiefexecutive.net/customer-service-is-your-marketing-strategy|work=November 26, 2013|publisher=Chief Executive|accessdate=25 April 2013}}{{cite web|last=March|first=Joshua|title=The Changing Nature of Customer Relationships|url=http://www.destinationcrm.com/Articles/Web-Exclusives/Viewpoints/The-Changing-Nature-of-Customer-Relationships-85621.aspx|work=October 19, 2013|publisher=Destination CRM|accessdate=25 April 2013}}{{cite web|last=March|first=Joshua|title=How to Turn Social Feedback into Valuable Business Data|url=http://mashable.com/2012/02/27/social-data-insights/|work=February 27, 2012|publisher=Mashable|accessdate=25 April 2013}} Previously Joshua and Dan Lester co-founded iPlatform, a social app development company, which was acquired by Betapond in September 2012. From 2008 to 2010 Joshua was the Chairman of the Facebook Developer Garage London, an official Facebook event running monthly for developers, entrepreneurs and marketers working on the Facebook platform, which he helped found in 2007. == Awards and recognition == Most recently, Conversocial was named a "cool vendor" in the CRM Customer Service and Social Report published by leading analyst firm [[Gartner]]{{cite news|last=Web|first=PR|title=Conversocial Named "Cool Vendor" by Leading Analyst Firm|url=http://markets.cbsnews.com/cbsnews/news/read/23979074/Conversocial_Named_|work=April 19, 2013|publisher=CBS Moneywatch|accessdate=25 April 2013}} The UK publication V3 has also named Conversocial one of Top 10 up-and-coming UK technology start-ups for 2013.{{cite web|last=Staff|first=V3|title=Top 10 up-and-coming UK technology start-ups|url=http://www.v3.co.uk/v3-uk/news/2261026/top-10-upandcoming-uk-startups|work=April 12, 2013|publisher=V3|accessdate=25 April 2013}} In 2010 Conversocial won "Highly Commended" in the Best Platform category of [[TechCrunch]]'s The Europas- European Startup Awards.{{cite web|last=Butcher|first=Mike|title=The Europas European Startup Awards 2010 – The Winners and Finalists|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/11/20/the-europas-european-startup-awards-2010-the-winners-and-finalists/|work=November 20, 2012|publisher=TechCrunch|accessdate=25 April 2013}} In 2011, Conversocial was the overall winner{{cite web|last=Butcher|first=Mike|title=PeerIndex Takes The Honours As The Europas Awards Drifts Eastwards|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/11/18/peer-index-takes-the-honours-as-the-europas-awards-drifts-east/|work=November 18, 2011|publisher=TechCrunch|accessdate=25 April 2013}} in the Best Advertising or Marketing Tech Startup category, and in 2013 they were "Highly Commended" in the Best Advertising or Marketing Tech Startup.{{cite web|last=Butcher|first=Mike|title=The Europas – Europe's Tech Startup Oscars – Showcases A Booming European Scene|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/01/22/the-europas-europes-tech-startup-oscars-showcases-a-booming-european-scene/|work=January 22, 2013|publisher=TechCrunch|accessdate=25 April 2013}} == References == == External links == * [http://www.conversocial.com Conversocial] [[Category:Companies established in 2009]] [[Category:Software companies based in New York (state)]] [[Category:Business software]] [[Category:Community building]] [[Category:Social networking services]] [[Category:Reputation management]] [[Category:Social information processing]]
